{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3480742,"name":"James","username":"Yoglbear","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/ac91a4/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T05:58:46.076Z","cooked":"

Does anyone have any guides or resources which can help with learning how to wire a elevator. I understand the basic information of FRC electrical but I wanna know if there is anything specific with wiring a elevator.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-13T05:58:46.076Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":277,"reads":445,"readers_count":444,"score":1474.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481337,"topic_slug":"elevator-electrical","display_username":"James","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71179,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-electrical/481337/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3480744,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T06:04:34.806Z","cooked":"

Wiring an elevator‚Ä¶

As in, wiring the drive motor(s) of the elevator, or running wiring to the top of the elevator?

If it‚Äôs the former, you wire it the same as any other motor on the base of the robot.

If it‚Äôs the latter, you want to run wire while extended to max height, and add a little extra. You‚Äôll take all that wire and bundle it together, probably in a cable track for protection, and secure it running up to the top of the first stage of the elevator. Other than that wiring run, everything else is basically the same as anything else on the robot.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-13T06:04:34.806Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":440,"readers_count":439,"score":233.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481337,"topic_slug":"elevator-electrical","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-electrical/481337/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482692,"name":"George Horsey","username":"GeorgeH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/georgeh/{size}/149009_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T22:45:30.634Z","cooked":"

As Eric said running in cable track will be best.

https://www.mcmaster.com/products/cable-tracks/

Plan out how many wires you will need and how much space they take up before purchasing cable track. The feed through kind will be more durable but a real pain if it is slightly too small hence the measuring before purchase.

You may consider a separate smaller cable track for sensor wiring. Though we have run power and sensor cabling together without issue.

Also consider making a separate branch of CAN so if anything happens and a wire gets broken in the cable track you will still have your drivetrain and possibly other mechanisms.

Label both ends of every wire BEFORE pushing it through the cable track.

Make sure the cable track is secured well and also plan to strain relief the wires coming out of it at both ends.

If possible slowly move everything by hand and making sure nothing will get pinched. If you have any joints that rotate run the wire near the pivot. Plastic wire loom is good to use if space is limited around a pivot to still protect the wire‚Äôs insulation.

My team was having trouble with the cable track swinging when driving, is there anywhere to get a guide for the cable track so that it sits how it should?

Multiple shorter lengths and polycarbonate guides is what we do to prevent the swinging.

For electronics on an extension, we use spring spiral wire. We found both this season and in 2023 that they worked quite well. We use a larger size to provide power to larger electronics, and an Ethernet cable in the same style to run CAN signals and lower voltages. Their primary downside is that they are a bit heavy, but the high reliability is a worthwhile tradeoff.
Here are the wires on the 2025 robot:

9KeTIez1920√ó1280 252 KB

And the 2023:
UxXFhvR1920√ó1280 280 KB

A few tips for cable track / Energy Chain (Igus, etc.) use.

  • Use a larger size track than you need.
    • Smaller tracks have a thinner plastic walls, allowing the links to flex and possibly come apart. This is a larger concern with high speed swerve drivetrains.
    • Smaller tracks do not handle the high momentum created by swerve drives in sideways directions. Try to mount the chain so the U shape is seen from the side of the robots normally traveled direction.
    • Smaller tracks are highly influenced by the cables inside them. You may have a track with a small bend radius, but the cables inside want to go back to their relaxed state, causing the track to bend out of the straight line path you want them to be in.
    • A larger bend radius track puts less wear on the wiring inside. We use machine tool sensor wire (Turck, Murr, IFm, etc.) for our can and sensor wires in energy chain because it has its own jacket, you can get it in 3 or 4 wire pair cables, and it is rated for the number of bend cycles seen by elevators.
  • Use polycarbonate or a tensioning device (constant force spring) to control where the chain runs, to keep it out of danger zones. See 2910 and other public CAD examples.
  • Energy chain with the split crossbars or snap open covers allow you to add or remove cables without having to feed from the very ends.
    • This season we used Igus E-Z chain E14 series chain, which allows you to add/remove cables from the outside of the bend radius. The Z series opens on the inside radius.
    • In 2023 we used the E08 series, and by the end of an offseason in September, the chain was starting to fall apart and get caught in our elevator.
  • Try not to twist wires inside the chain. You want a wire to start and end in the same location of the chain. Twists or criss-crosses inside the chain will cause chafing, and will eventually break or short out your wire run.
  • You can often use a single run of chain for your elevator as long as the fixed end is as high as possible and the moving point is mounted low on the carriage. We have 60" of total carriage travel and used a single chain run.

Igus Run1920√ó1484 70.3 KB
